docs.lead_paragraph: A neural network of computer processors, fed millions of YouTube videos, taught itself to recognize cats, a feat of significance for fields like speech recognition.
docs.abstract: Google scientists created one of the largest neural networks for machine learning by connecting 16,000 computer processors, which they then turned loose on the Internet to independently learn; network, presented with 10 million digital images found in YouTube videos, taught itself to recognize cats, a feat of significance for fields like speech recognition.
docs.snippet: A neural network of computer processors, fed millions of YouTube videos, taught itself to recognize cats, a feat of significance for fields like speech recognition....

headline.print_headline: How Many Computers to Identify a Cat? 16,000
headline.seo: In a Big Network of Computers, Evidence of Machine Learning
headline.main: How Many Computers to Identify a Cat? 16,000

docs.lead_paragraph: MANY people come to the small gray building at the end of the Macmillan Wharf here prepared to be hoodwinked. They have seen the skull-and-crossbones flag and are certain the place must be a tourist trap. Then they step inside and see a ship's bell, covered with algae, inscribed ''The Whydah Gally 1716.'' What they have entered is the Expedition Whydah Sea Lab and Learning Center, which since 1997 has housed the 200,000 artifacts collected over many years from the first authentic pirate ship ever recovered.
docs.abstract: Whydah Sea Lab and Learning Center in Provincetown, Mass, houses 200,000 artifacts from Whydah, first authentic pirate ship ever recovered; Whydah sank off Cape Cod in 1717; photo (Special section, Museums) (M)
